Module MathUtils
Package mathUtils.calculus.complex

Class ComplexMath

java.lang.Object
mathUtils.calculus.complex.ComplexMath
public final class ComplexMath
extends java.lang.Object
This class is an extension to the MathTools class. It computes calculations for real, imaginary and complex numbers. Note that using this class, along with calculations with complex numbers, should be done by using exclusively instances of java.lang.Number, since anything else would include a very verbose series of casting, which may result into errors. Even though this method seems esoteric and awkward at first, it is the only solution to the problem at the current moment.

How To Work With Numbers

Let us say that we want to take the square root of an unknown number \( x \); We know that the result is a real number if \( x \) is positive, however, if \( x \) is negative the result is an imaginary number. Therefore the result is an instance of any two possible classes. Now, to express this operation we would write:

Number x = -5;
Number y = ComplexMath.sqrt(x);
System.out.println( y.toString() );

This code would output 25i, since y is now an instance of Imaginary. However, if x were positive, then y would be an instance of Double, since the result is a real number.

What To Avoid

What I just showed you are the conventions, but you could achieve the same result by continuously casting numbers, like this:

double x = -5;
Imaginary y = (Imaginary) ComplexTools.sqrt(x);
System.out.println( y.toString() );

This approach is deprecated and should not be used; Not only is it very verbose to do so, but it could lead to potential errors. For example, suppose that x is thoroughly unknown to us and it could be both positive and negative; Our program might throw a ClassCastException, because ComplexMath.sqrt(x) can not only return an instance of Imaginary, but also an instance of Double, which results in an error.

See Also:
Imaginary, Complex, MathTools

      Parameters:

    • arg

      public static double arg​(java.lang.Number n)
      Returns the complex argument of the given number. If the number is not complex, then it is made such by appending a 'zero'-value to its counterpart (Real / Imaginary). The output is given in radians and is clamped in the interval \( (-\pi; \pi] \). It is equivalent to Math.atan2(i, r), where i and r are the imaginary and real parts of the complex number respectively.
      Parameters:
      n - The number whose complex argument should be evaluated
      Returns:
      The argument of the given number

    • ln

      public static java.lang.Number ln​(java.lang.Number n)
      Calculates the natural logarithm of the given number. The logarithm has, as per definition, a base of \( e \).
      Parameters:
      n - The number whose natural logarithm should be calculated
      Returns:
      The natural logarithm of the number

    • log

      public static java.lang.Number log​(java.lang.Number n)
      Calculates the logarithm of this number. It simply delegates to ComplexMath.ln(n). This method is redundant per se, but was added nonetheless in order to correctly extend Math.log(n).
      Parameters:
      n - The number whose logarithm should be calculated
      Returns:
      The logarithm of this function

    • log

      public static java.lang.Number log​(java.lang.Number n, java.lang.Number base)
      Calculates the logarithm with the given base of this number. As per definition, it is said that \( |log_b(a) = |frac{\log a}{\log b} \).
      Parameters:
      n - The number whose logarithm should be calculated
      base - The base of the logarithm
      Returns:
      The logarith with the given base of the given number

    • round

      public static java.lang.Number round​(java.lang.Number n, int decimal)
      Rounds the given number to the given decimal. If the given number is complex, then both the real and imaginary parts are rounded. If the given decimal is negative, then the number is rounded to the nearest decimal.
      Parameters:
      n - The number to round
      decimal - The decimal to round the number to
      Returns:
      The rounded number

    • sum

      public java.lang.Number sum​(int a, int b, ComplexFunction f)
      Computes the sum from \(a\) to \(b\) for the given function \(f\). It is equivalent to:

      \( \displaystyle\sum\limits_{k=a}^b f(k) \)

      This can be written as:
      sum(a, b, f);
      To describe a function where you need to use the index of the summation as a variable, like:

      \( f(z) = \displaystyle\sum\limits_{k=a}^b z^k \)

      You should write:
      Function f = z -> sum(a, b, k -> pow(z, k);
      For \( a > b \) the result is always \(0\).
      Parameters:
      a - The lower bound of the sum
      b - The upper bound of the sum
      f - The function to summate
      Returns:
      The sum

    • product

      public static java.lang.Number product​(int a, int b, ComplexFunction f)
      Computes the product from \(a\) to \(b\) for the given function \(f\). It is equivalent to:

      \( \displaystyle\prod\limits_{k=a}^b f(k) \)

      This can be written as:
      product(a, b, f);
      To describe a function where you need to use the index of the product as a variable, like:

      \( f(z) = \displaystyle\prod\limits_{k=a}^b z^k} \)

      You should write:
      Function f = z -> product(a, b, k -> pow(z, k);
      For \( a > b \) the result is always \(0\).
      Parameters:
      a - The lower bound of the product
      b - The upper bound of the product
      f - The function to multiply
      Returns:
      The product

    • limit

      public static java.lang.Number limit​(java.lang.Number n, ComplexFunction f)
